commit_message:
Cleanup of pom.xml

This patch works thanks to a fix in clouddocs-maven-plugin 1.14.

For Install and Config Guide:
* Remove targetDirectory variable, the default is fine
* Properly set webhelpDirname
* Remove cleanup section that are not needed anymore due to the above
  changes

Change-Id: I68ba45af7e870f888b2a39c5526b71802e1ebab4

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: make default storage driver

It's default under drivers:storage:sqlalchemy

Updates the sample configuration file to use sqlalchemy by default,
Also replaces instances of sqlite in config defaults throughout the storage layer with sqlalchemy.

Change-Id: If52910b36498b2e4ee5322e46765f8c42130e978

commit_message:
Migrate pre-validation HOT templates to proper schema

Patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69655 added stricter validation
to the HOT template schema. This data migration patch converts existing
stacks that may have been created prior to the validation using
non-conforming or proposed syntax.

Change-Id: I0e6c928093c3eb30b583d618ec6c51d6bcb7fa21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/94/78094/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import copy import re from migrate.versioning import util as migrate_util from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker from heat.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ from heat.db.sqlalchemy import models def upgrade(migrate_engine): Session = sessionmaker(bind=migrate_engine) session = Session() raw_templates = session.query(models.RawTemplate).all() for raw_template in raw_templates: if ('heat_template_version' in raw_template.template and 'parameters' in raw_template.template): template = copy.deepcopy(raw_template.template) for parameter, schema in template['parameters'].iteritems(): changed = False def _commit_schema(parameter, schema): template['parameters'][parameter] = schema raw_template.template = template session.commit() if 'required' in schema: del schema['required'] changed = True if 'constrants' in schema: schema['constraints'] = schema['constrants'] del schema['constrants'] changed = True if 'constraints' in schema: constraints = schema['constraints'] for func in ('allowedPattern', 'allowedValues'): if func in constraints: new_func = '_'.join(w.lower() for w in re.findall('[A-Z]?[a-z]+', func)) constraints[new_func] = constraints[func] del constraints[func] changed = True schema['constraints'] = constraints if changed: _commit_schema(parameter, schema) def downgrade(migrate_engine): migrate_util.log.warning(_('This version cannot be downgraded because ' 'it involves a data migration to the ' 'raw_template table.'))

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-05 06:10:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/a614ed2c41a2d9129abb730565bf95251f4d3fde', 'message': "Modify python-dateutil RPM build process

commit_message:
Modify python-dateutil RPM build process

The current build process for the python-dateutil RPM generates a
package that when installed lays a number of files on a filesystem
that only root can read.  This is problematic for non-root owned
processes that are trying to read these files.  Adding this patch
opens up those files to reading by process that aren't running as
root.  For example, this would allow for the running of the
reference uWSGI based implementation as a non-root user.

Fixes: bug #1288033
Change-Id: I3bff45bab272de888992cb42a8b8709a3fcd8ec6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/09/78109/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ################################################################################ # Modified python-dateutil RPM build process via fpm # # python-dateutil RPM file permissions are too restrictive when generated by a # # default fpm call, i.e. fpm -s python -t rpm python-dateutil, so this # # modified process addresses that problem. # ################################################################################ pypi_pdu_version="python-dateutil-2.2" pypi_pdu_version_md5="c1f654d0ff7e33999380a8ba9783fd5c" fpm_tmp_dir=$(mktemp -d --suffix=-fpm-python-dateutil) if [ $? -eq 1 ] then echo "Unable to create tmp dir for python-dateutil fpm build." 1>&2 exit 1 fi wget -P $fpm_tmp_dir \ https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/p/python-dateutil/\ $pypi_pdu_version.tar.gz --no-check-certificate echo "$pypi_pdu_version_md5 $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version.tar.gz" \ | md5sum -c - if [ $? -eq 1 ] then echo "The md5 check for python-dateutil from pypi failed." 1>&2 rm -rf $fpm_tmp_dir exit 1 fi tar xvfz $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version.tar.gz -C $fpm_tmp_dir find $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version/python_dateutil.egg-info -type f \ -exec chmod go+r {} \; chmod go+rx $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version/python_dateutil.egg-info chmod go+r \ $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version/dateutil/zoneinfo/zoneinfo--latest.tar.gz fpm -s python -t rpm $fpm_tmp_dir/$pypi_pdu_version/setup.py rm -rf $fpm_tmp_dir ################################################ # End python-dateutil modified fpm build process ################################################
deleted_lines: fpm -s python -t rpm python-dateutil # --> python-dateutil 1.4.1-6.el6 exists, but is incompatible

commit_message:
No longer call check_uptodate.sh in pep8

check_uptodate.sh re-generates a nova.conf.sample and then compares
it, which was fine. It stopped being fine when we started pulling in
options from oslo, or other modules made releases and then the gate
broke until we fixed the config sample.

Change-Id: I04b2b52a9e46dcf5f4f06e639327f22b827ccd0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/78028/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update "Create Volume Snapshot" description

The right side of the "Create Volume Snapshot" dialog contained information
from the "Create Volume" dialog's right side.  Now, it contains text more
appropriate to creating snapshots.

Change-Id: I97768744ed6ea36ed2f99988a5fe8c968fcbd941
Closes-Bug: #1275935

added_lines:
Description of configuration options for exchange
Configuration option = Default value Description
[DEFAULT]
cinder_control_exchange = cinder (StrOpt) Exchange name for Cinder notifications.
control_exchange = openstack (StrOpt) AMQP exchange to connect to if using RabbitMQ or Qpid
default_publisher_id = None (StrOpt) Default publisher_id for outgoing notifications
glance_control_exchange = glance (StrOpt) Exchange name for Glance notifications.
heat_control_exchange = heat (StrOpt) Exchange name for Heat notifications
http_control_exchanges = ['nova', 'glance', 'neutron', 'cinder'] (MultiStrOpt) Exchanges name to listen for notifications.
neutron_control_exchange = neutron (StrOpt) Exchange name for Neutron notifications.
nova_control_exchange = nova (StrOpt) Exchange name for Nova notifications.
sample_source = openstack (StrOpt) Source for samples emitted on this instance.

commit_message:
swift classes need to include swift::params

Some of the swift classes use parameterized settings defined in
swift::params but do not include the swift::params class.

Change-Id: I7704bf42db4554566d27b510bbbedb8afe0fe7b3
Closes-Bug: #1288252
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/02/78302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: include swift::params

commit_message:
Support specifying which cartridges are installed on node

The openshift.sh script supports specifying cartridges installed. The
CONF_CARTRIDGES env variable support a comma-separated list or a class
of cartriges "all" or "standard." A prepended minus sign '-' in a list
of carts will negate the list.

Change-Id: I6ae0d29bc397b51a5b7353b8b51bf5d2b1fcba7b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/72/77772/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - cartridges cartridges: description: > Cartridges to install. "all" for all cartridges; "standard" for all cartridges except for JBossEWS or JBossEAP type: string default: standard export CONF_CARTRIDGES=P_CONF_CARTRIDGES P_CONF_CARTRIDGES: { get_param: cartridges }

commit_message:
Generic Multiplexed method

Drivers with VendorInterface, provide different vendor_passthru methods.
MultipleVendorInterface allows to mixin the different drivers. If different
drivers provide the same method, the first specified driver is the one
providing it. This can be overrided using extra_mappings.

* Allows multiple vendors
driver.vendor = utils.MixedVendorInterface(pxe, ipminative, seamicro)

* Allows override methods via extra_mappings
extra_mapping = {'set_boot_device': pxe,
                 'continue_deploy': ipminative,
                 'set_vlan': ipmi_tool}
driver.vendor = utils.MixedVendorInterface(pxe, ipminative, extra_mappings=extra_mappings)

* Or indicate the methods to use just using extra_mappings
extra_mapping = {'set_boot_device': pxe,
                 'continue_deploy': ipminative,
                 'set_vlan': ipmi_tool}
driver.vendor = utils.MixedVendorInterface(extra_mappings=extra_mappings)

Partial-Bug: #1264596
Change-Id: Id93db7eb802f2414b4685b298062608a4f4be600
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/22/73322/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # coding=utf-8 # Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from ironic.common import exception from ironic.drivers import utils from ironic.tests import base class FakeA(object): VENDOR_PASSTHRU_METHODS = ['method_a', 'method_c'] class VendorPassthru(): def method_a(self): pass def method_c(self): pass def validate(self): pass def vendor_passthru(self): pass class FakeB(object): VENDOR_PASSTHRU_METHODS = ['method_b', 'method_c'] class VendorPassthru(): def method_b(self): pass def method_c(self): pass class UtilsTestCase(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(UtilsTestCase, self).setUp() def test_uniq_vendor(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_a'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_c'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) def test_multiple_vendor(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA, FakeB) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_a'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_c'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_b'], FakeB.VendorPassthru) def test_extra_mapping(self): extra_mapping = {'method_c': FakeB} vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA, FakeB, extra_mapping=extra_mapping) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_a'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_c'], FakeB.VendorPassthru) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_b'], FakeB.VendorPassthru) def test_only_extra_mmaping(self): extra_mapping = {'method_a': FakeA} vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface( extra_mapping=extra_mapping) self.assertIsInstance(vendor.mapping['method_a'], FakeA.VendorPassthru) def test_vendor_interface_validate_valid_methods(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA) with mock.patch.object(FakeA.VendorPassthru, 'validate') as mock_validate: vendor.validate(method='method_a') mock_validate.assert_called_once_with(method='method_a') def test_vendor_interface_validate_bad_method(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA) self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameterValue, vendor.validate, method='fake_method') def test_vendor_interface_validate_none_method(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA) self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameterValue, vendor.validate) def test_vendor_interface_route_valid_method(self): vendor = utils.MultipleVendorInterface(FakeA) with mock.patch.object(FakeA.VendorPassthru, 'vendor_passthru') as mock_method: vendor.vendor_passthru('task', 'node', method='method_a', param1='fake1', param2='fake2') mock_method.assert_called_once_with('task', 'node', method='method_a', param1='fake1', param2='fake2')

commit_message:
Update 3PAR block storage docs

Document the new QoS settings for the HP 3PAR client.
They are now using the qos_specs instead on putting
them in the extra_specs. Also, qos_specs do not require
the scoping of the keys like the extra_specs did.

Added two new personas along with a few minor edit.

Change-Id: Ibbbf430dd19744e7c45e6e7e4f8374bb61606535
Closes-Bug: #1283181
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/96/76996/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <literal>hp3par:</literal>. <screen>$cinder help type-key</screen> the <literal>1 - Generic</literal> persona. The valid values are, <literal>1 - Generic</literal>, - AIX-legacy</literal>, <literal>9 - ONTAP-legacy</literal>, <literal>11 - VMware</literal>, <literal>12 - OpenVMS</literal>, <literal>13 - HPUX</literal>, and <literal>15 - WindowsServer</literal>.</para> <para>QoS support for both HP 3PAR drivers includes the ability to set the following capabilities in the OpenStack Cinder API <filename>cinder.api.contrib.qos_specs_manage</filename> qos specs extension module:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para><literal>minBWS</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>maxBWS</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>minIOPS</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>maxIOPS</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>latency</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>priority</literal></para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>The qos keys above no longer require to be scoped but must be created and associated to a volume type. For information about how to set the key-value pairs and associate them with a volume type, run the following commands: <screen>$cinder help qos-create</screen> <screen>$cinder help qos-key</screen> <screen>$cinder help qos-associate</screen> </para> <para>The following keys require that the HP 3PAR StoreServ storage array has a Priority Optimization license installed.</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para><literal>hp3par:vvs</literal> - The virtual volume set name that has been predefined by the Administrator with Quality of Service (QoS) rules associated to it. If you specify extra_specs <literal>hp3par:vvs</literal>, the qos_specs <literal>min/maxIOPS</literal> and <literal>min/maxBWS</literal> settings are ignored.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>minBWS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue bandwidth minimum goal in MBs. If not set, the I/O issue bandwidth rate has no minimum goal.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>maxBWS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue bandwidth rate limit in MBs. If not set, the I/O issue bandwidth rate has no limit.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>minIOPS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue count minimun goal. If not set, the I/O issue count has no minimum goal.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>maxIOPS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue count rate limit. If not set, the I/O issue count rate has no limit.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>latency</literal> - The latency goal in milliseconds.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>priority</literal> - The priority of the QoS rule over other rules. If not set, the priority is normal, valid values are low, normal and high.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <note> <para>Since the Icehouse release, minIOPS and maxIOPS must be used together to set I/O limits. Similarly, minBWS and maxBWS must be used together. If only one is set the other will be set to the same value.</para> </note>
deleted_lines: <listitem> <para><literal>qos:maxBWS</literal></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>qos:maxIOPS</literal></para> </listitem> <literal>hp3par:</literal> or <literal>qos:</literal>. <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput> cinder help type-key</userinput></screen> <para>The following keys require that the HP 3PAR StoreServ storage array has a Priority Optimization license installed.</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para><literal>hp3par:vvs</literal> - The virtual volume set name that has been predefined by the Administrator with Quality of Service (QoS) rules associated to it. If you specify <literal>hp3par:vvs</literal>, the <literal>qos:maxIOPS</literal> and <literal>qos:maxBWS</literal> settings are ignored.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>qos:maxBWS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue count rate limit in MBs. If not set, the I/O issue bandwidth rate has no limit.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><literal>qos:maxIOPS</literal> - The QoS I/O issue count rate limit. If not set, the I/O issue count rate has no limit.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> the <literal>1 – Generic</literal> persona. The valid values are, <literal>1 – Generic</literal>, - AIX-legacy</literal>, <literal>9 – ONTAP-legacy</literal>, <literal>11 – VMware</literal>, and <literal>12 - OpenVMS</literal>.</para>

subject: fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-20 19:57:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/581206a7de0616add7e93099e98c7ab52b299df1', 'message': 'fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors.

When a primary MongoDB node fails over to a secondary, pymongo raises an
AutoReconnect error. Let's catch that and retry the operation so that
we truly our Highly Available (in the sense that the user will never notice
the few ms of "downtime" caused by a failover).

Closes-Bug: 1214973
Change-Id: Ibf172e30ec6e7fa0bbb8fdcebda9e985d1e49714
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-02-22 00:19:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/fd422d4b2756fd3006a04a4fcd02d01a5d70c21d', 'message': 'fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors

When a primary MongoDB node fails over to a secondary, pymongo raises an
AutoReconnect error. Let's catch that and retry the operation so that
we truly our Highly Available (in the sense that the user will never notice
the few ms of "downtime" caused by a failover).

Closes-Bug: 1214973
Change-Id: Ibf172e30ec6e7fa0bbb8fdcebda9e985d1e49714
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-03-03 17:58:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/1d84a2c27469f1fc27dc5e8fde1ae2823842d4de', 'message': 'fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors

When a primary MongoDB node fails over to a secondary, pymongo raises an
AutoReconnect error. Let's catch that and retry the operation so that
we truly are Highly Available (in the sense that the user will never notice
the few ms of "downtime" caused by a failover).

This is particularly important when hosting backend with a DBaaS that
routinely fails over the master as a way of compacting shards.

Closes-Bug: 1214973
Change-Id: Ibf172e30ec6e7fa0bbb8fdcebda9e985d1e49714
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-03-03 18:05:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/da73780074fd29212f918c64fafd406b6839079b', 'message': 'fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors

When a primary MongoDB node fails over to a secondary, pymongo raises an
AutoReconnect error. Let's catch that and retry the operation so that
we truly are Highly Available (in the sense that the user will never notice
the few ms of "downtime" caused by a failover).

commit_message:
fix(MongoDB): Driver does not retry on AutoReconnect errors

When a primary MongoDB node fails over to a secondary, pymongo raises an
AutoReconnect error. Let's catch that and retry the operation so that
we truly are Highly Available (in the sense that the user will never notice
the few ms of "downtime" caused by a failover).

This is particularly important when hosting backend with a DBaaS that
routinely fails over the master as a way of compacting shards.

NOTE: In order to get all MongoDB tests green, a tiny unrelated bug in
test_shards was fixed as part of this patch.

Closes-Bug: 1214973
Change-Id: Ibf172e30ec6e7fa0bbb8fdcebda9e985d1e49714

added_lines: import timefrom marconi.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ """Handles the MongoDB ConnectionFailure error. This decorator catches MongoDB's ConnectionFailuredef retries_on_autoreconnect(max_attempts=5, sleep=0.020): """Causes the wrapped function to be recalled on AutoReconnect. :param max_attempts: (Default 5) Maximum number of times to try calling the wrapped function before giving up and re-raising the exception. :param sleep: (Default 0.01) Baseline number of seconds to sleep between attempts. The actual sleep time doubles on each attempt to avoid thundering-herd issues. For example, given the default of 10 ms, sleep time will be: 20, 40, 80, 160 and 320 ms. """ def decorator(func): """Handles the MongoDB AutoReconnect error. This decorator catches MongoDB's AutoReconnect error and retries the function call. WARNING: The decorated function must be idempotent. """ @functools.wraps(func) def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): for attempt in range(max_attempts): try: return func(*args, **kwargs) break except errors.AutoReconnect as ex: LOG.warn(_(u'Caught AutoReconnect, retrying the ' 'call to {0}').format(func)) time.sleep(sleep * (2 ** attempt)) else: LOG.error(_(u'Caught AutoReconnect, maximum attempts ' 'to {0} exceeded.').format(func)) raise ex return wrapper return decorator

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Set permissions on qcow2 snapshot files

The GlusterFS driver sets specific permissions on the
volume file when volumes are created.  Setting them on the
snapshot files at snapshot creation time is also required,
otherwise volume attaches will fail for volumes with snapshots
when using QEMU's libgfapi functionality.

This does not weaken the current security model in any
significant way, as it only lines up the permissions used
for snapshot files with those already used for volume files.

This will eventually be addressed by functionality in libvirt:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1052014

Closes-Bug: #1286376

Change-Id: I93944724c557c907eb3821a061e7434f09ff20bc

commit_message:
Add a missing space in a log message.

It's easy to accidentally forget to add a space between words when splitting a
message up across multiple lines.  I noticed this case while working on some
other code.  Fix it up.

Change-Id: I0d714c0932834a15fb68f26f484495ccccb5a6ad

commit_message:
Separate negative tests for test_server_addresses

Move negative tests from test_server_addresses.py to
test_server_addresses_negative.py.

Partially implements blueprint negative-test-files

Change-Id: Ifde8041dbf15224f5611b4c4b07be563a3101db6

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest import config from tempest import exceptions from tempest import test CONF = config.CONF class ServerAddressesV3NegativeTest(base.BaseV3ComputeTest): _interface = 'json' @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): # This test module might use a network and a subnet cls.set_network_resources(network=True, subnet=True) super(ServerAddressesV3NegativeTest, cls).setUpClass() cls.client = cls.servers_client resp, cls.server = cls.create_test_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_list_server_addresses_invalid_server_id(self): # List addresses request should fail if server id not in system self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.list_addresses, '999') @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_list_server_addresses_by_network_neg(self): # List addresses by network should fail if network name not valid self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.list_addresses_by_network, self.server['id'], 'invalid')

commit_message:
update test to hit default page instead of login

With Django 1.6, the test are failing to load the login page
with 'openstack_auth.user.Token object is not JSON serializable'
error.

Partially-implements blueprint django-1point6

Change-Id: I8b3d62f3076d6d2071ba77848b83e1872ba69ba6

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-26 22:02:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/dcffdc884e7135e02a2ac64cdefc8f445630ced2', 'message': 'Nova server to ref cloud-config resources in user_data

With this change is is now possible to do boot-time cloud-init configuration using
some combination of OS::Heat::MultipartMime, OS::Heat::CloudConfig or
OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig.

Cloud-init configuration is specified by referencing the resource
in the user_data when user_data_format=RAW:

  server:
    type: OS::Nova::Server
    properties:
      ...
      user_data_format: RAW
      user_data:
        get_resource: server_init

Alternatively, the config can be fetched as a string attribute
from the OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig config attribute:

  server:
    type: OS::Nova::Server
    properties:
      ...
      user_data_format: RAW
      user_data:
        get_attr: [server_init, config]

implements blueprint cloud-init-resource

commit_message:
Nova server to ref cloud-config resources in user_data

With this change it is now possible to do boot-time cloud-init configuration
using some combination of OS::Heat::MultipartMime, OS::Heat::CloudConfig or
OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig.

Cloud-init configuration is specified by referencing the resource
in the user_data when user_data_format=RAW:

  server:
    type: OS::Nova::Server
    properties:
      ...
      user_data_format: RAW
      user_data:
        get_resource: server_init

Alternatively, the config can be fetched as a string attribute
from the OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig config attribute:

  server:
    type: OS::Nova::Server
    properties:
      ...
      user_data_format: RAW
      user_data:
        get_attr: [server_init, config]

implements blueprint cloud-init-resource
Change-Id: I72f74d302afd71dac3845282dcc9a1ca83e92149

Add support for claims

Implements blueprint claims-management
Change-Id: Icaa7c6df73e13200fc3ba03c34e90c5ac850eb46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/14/72614/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def claim_create(transport, request, queue_name, **kwargs): """Creates a Claim `claim_id` on the queue `queue_name` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` """ request.operation = 'claim_create' request.params['queue_name'] = queue_name request.content = json.dumps(kwargs) resp = transport.send(request) return resp.deserialized_content def claim_get(transport, request, queue_name, claim_id): """Gets a Claim `claim_id` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` """ request.operation = 'claim_get' request.params['queue_name'] = queue_name request.params['claim_id'] = claim_id resp = transport.send(request) return resp.deserialized_content def claim_update(transport, request, queue_name, claim_id, callback=None): """Updates a Claim `claim_id` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` """ request.operation = 'claim_update' request.params['queue_name'] = queue_name request.params['claim_id'] = claim_id resp = transport.send(request) return resp.deserialized_content def claim_delete(transport, request, queue_name, claim_id): """Deletes a Claim `claim_id` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` """ request.operation = 'claim_get' request.params['queue_name'] = queue_name request.params['claim_id'] = claim_id transport.send(request)

commit_message:
Set primary controller role before priorities assignment

If nodes were passed as unsorted list
then there was a problem with wrong priorities
assignment, we have to assign primary-controller
role and only after that set priorities.

Change-Id: I35b824d316261ad555aa555ed5e34afb5857dc8d
Closes-bug: #1287656
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/76/78176/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_set_primary_controller_priority_not_depend_on_nodes_order(self): controllers = filter(lambda n: 'controller' in n.roles, self.env.nodes) expected_primary_controller = sorted( controllers, key=lambda c: c.id)[0] reverse_sorted_controllers = sorted( controllers, key=lambda c: c.id, reverse=True) result_nodes = self.serializer.serialize( self.cluster, reverse_sorted_controllers) high_priority = sorted(result_nodes, key=lambda n: n['priority'])[0] self.assertEquals(high_priority['role'], 'primary-controller') self.assertEquals( int(high_priority['uid']), expected_primary_controller.id)

commit_message:
Allow LiveBlockMigrationV3Test to be skipped if v3 is disabled

The tearDown for LiveBlockMigrationV3Test fails as
self.created_server_ids is initialized after calling
the parent's setUpClass (which in the case of a disabled v3 test,
triggers the tearDown)

Change-Id: Id02e0458883db8b4e64f747b7cc0969684448b9e
Closes-Bug: 1282827

added_lines: cls.created_server_ids = []

commit_message:
Only execute tearDown if setUpClass created cls.volume

If the v3 api is skipped, the setUpClass will not create
cls.volume. The tearDown method must then check if cls.volume
exists before referencing it.

Change-Id: Ie187781cb9ab0371fed49c423c55b694a3c397c4
Closes-Bug: 1282829

commit_message:
Skip deleting flavors in tearDown if setUpClass did not complete

The setUpClass method will not configure cls.client if the v3 api is
disabled per configuration. We must check if cls.client exists before
accessing it in tearDown.

This applies to FlavorExtraSpecs and its negative tests.

Change-Id: I885dad27b6be98c3a3ba52178c19983c4d461fa4
Closes-Bug: #1282839

Added several pacakges to global requirements

OpenStack Murano project components are require the following
packages, which are not presented in global requirements yet:

This commit adds these requirements to the list of global requirements.

commit_message:
Check self links for consumer get and list tests

Add asserts to check if the self link is correct for the get and
list tests for consumer.

Also created a class variable for '/OS-OAUTH1/consumers' instead
of having it hard coded in a bunch of spots.

Partially fixes Bug: #1279492

Change-Id: Ib9259e65b37507ee49416d7ac8c738fbfd1d329c

commit_message:
Stop gating on up-to-date sample config file.

The sample config file could get out of date if any of the oslo
libraries changed under us, which would cause everything to fail.
Rather than get blocked by library changes, this check will not be
done anymore.

Change-Id: I96ac66ca9d01a08274c00c98f37453e299ef5423
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/30/78030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix regex for file size to parse float-style numbers properly

The SIZE_RE regex was not accounting for the fact that the size of the
file can be reported as a float style number (eg '2.0G') and so the size
of the file was not being reported in bytes correctly.

Change-Id: I9c820be287da32f3853bf9af5606cbbaf714e843
Closes-Bug: #1285764
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/12/76912/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SIZE_RE = re.compile(r"([\d\.]+)(\w+)?(\s*\(\s*(\d+)\s+bytes\s*\))?", re.I)

commit_message:
Add "delete the resized server" tests

This patch adds "delete the resized server" tests.

Change-Id: I8f753df0f3eb5e921383134835db4c0efba4575a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/67/75767/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import testtools @testtools.skipIf(not CONF.compute_feature_enabled.resize, 'Resize not available.') @test.attr(type='gate') def test_delete_server_while_in_verify_resize_state(self): # Delete a server while it's VM state is VERIFY_RESIZE resp, server = self.create_test_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') resp, body = self.client.resize(server['id'], self.flavor_ref_alt) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) self.client.wait_for_server_status(server['id'], 'VERIFY_RESIZE') resp, _ = self.client.delete_server(server['id']) self.assertEqual('204', resp['status'])

revisions:

commit_message:
Fix animation on pie charts

Animation on pie charts in Project > Overview and Admin > Hypervisros
does not start at 0 degree which, depending on the percentage used
for a resource, could cause the pie chart animate counter-clockwise.
This patch fixes the issue by setting the start angle to 0 degree.

The patch also fixes the issue with the last pie chart where it does
not animate.

Closes-Bug: #1283306
Change-Id: Ibc7f676f522a7e3ea69f87f36898249ecd0fe326
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/45/76645/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.current.startAngle = 0; //FIXME (vahid hashemian): the following line is to make sure the last pie chart is filled properly a.startAngle = 2 * Math.PI * (100 - a.value) / 100;

subject: Remove str() from LOG.* and exceptions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-26 21:39:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/99aa9815192ee634c4300b0b31c93746b04cf8b1', 'message': "Switch str() to six.text_type() for LOG/exceptions

This commit removes the use of str() from LOG.* messages
and exceptions.  It switches to the safer six.text_type() function.
The reason we need to remove str() is because str() will fail if
it gets a Unicode string that has something that doesn't translate
to ASCII in it.  If such a situation is encountered you will lose
the message string in question.  Additionally, gettextutils is
assuming that the strings it receives will be Unicode strings.
Making this change is a step towards satisfying that assumption.

The reason for using six.text_type is because in Py2.X there is a
'unicode' function.  In Py3, however, instead of using 'unicode'
the function will be called 'string'.  six.text_type will provide
compatibility for both Python levels in this case.

Change-Id: I6eb81043edd9fa5e035d81ee81e8439340546d24
Closes-bug: 1274245
Related-bp: i18n-messages
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-02-28 21:59:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6734bf23310168b58e31ee15df447f2d47a7815b', 'message': "Remove str() from LOG.* and exceptions

This commit removes the use of str() from LOG.* messages
and exceptions.

The reason we need to remove str() is because str() will fail if
it gets a Unicode string that has something that doesn't translate
to ASCII in it.  If such a situation is encountered you will lose
the message string in question.  In most cases, the use of str() is
unnecessary for LOG.* and exception messages.  Using %s is smart
enough to figure out what to do with what it is passed.  It first
tries to str() it, if this fails it falls back to using unicode.  Either
way, the result will then be something that gettextutils can
handle and translate.

Change-Id: I6eb81043edd9fa5e035d81ee81e8439340546d24
Closes-bug: 1274245
Related-bp: i18n-messages
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-03-03 05:04:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7840dad2c3c3a5a42b57934bad99e95b664c923c', 'message': "Remove str() from LOG.* and exceptions

This commit removes the use of str() from LOG.* messages
and exceptions.

The reason we need to remove str() is because str() will fail if
it gets a Unicode string that has something that doesn't translate
to ASCII in it.  If such a situation is encountered you will lose
the message string in question.  In most cases, the use of str() is
unnecessary for LOG.* and exception messages.  Using %s is smart
enough to figure out what to do with what it is passed.  It first
tries to str() it, if this fails it falls back to using unicode.  Either
way, the result will then be something that gettextutils can
handle and translate.

Change-Id: I6eb81043edd9fa5e035d81ee81e8439340546d24
Closes-bug: 1274245
Related-bp: i18n-messages
"}]
commit_message:
Remove str() from LOG.* and exceptions

This commit removes the use of str() from LOG.* messages
and exceptions.

The reason we need to remove str() is because str() will fail if
it gets a Unicode string that has something that doesn't translate
to ASCII in it.  If such a situation is encountered you will lose
the message string in question.  In most cases, the use of str() is
unnecessary for LOG.* and exception messages.  Using %s is smart
enough to figure out what to do with what it is passed.  It first
tries to str() it, if this fails it falls back to using unicode.  Either
way, the result will then be something that gettextutils can
handle and translate.

Change-Id: I6eb81043edd9fa5e035d81ee81e8439340546d24
Closes-bug: 1274245
Related-bp: i18n-messages

commit_message:
Quota delete operation in cinder

This change adds the quota-delete operation to cinder.

It is adding the api and the tests, using the methods already
implemented in the db to destroy all the quotas for a specific
project.

Implements blueprint quota-delete

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia040a20abb831c311eb13624ddecbbf0f12fdd9f

commit_message:
Allow Messages in NotImplementedErrors

If print'd or str()'d a regular NotImplementedError that was created
with a translatable Message will raise an exception because it will try
to str() the underlying Message, which is already a text type, but
str()'ing a Message is not allowed.

This patch overrides the default behavior in a new class called
LocalizableNotImplementedError to remove that problem. Without this, if
a NotImplementedError reaches WSME it would break because exceptions in
WSME are str()'d.

Change-Id: Ieb306511a2237bea7e5b5a2daf7fc996317d1571
Partial-Bug: #1275901

commit_message:
Add support for libvirt secret management

This change adds support for libvirt secret management to the libvirt
driver, providing create, delete, and existence methods for libvirt
secrets. Support for creating and parsing libvirt secret XML is
included, along with a designer method for instantiating a libvirt
secret with standard options. Additional test cases and a new libvirt
driver test suite are also included.

This patch is the first in a series that will add support for qcow2
ephemeral storage encryption. For more information, see the blueprint
linked below:

blueprint encrypt-ephemeral-storage

Change-Id: I074753679b7994ece123abc282497b2ee860f3bc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/68285/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.tests import matchers from nova.virt.libvirt import config def test_set_secret_config(self): """ Test the setting of libvirt secret attributes, verifying that individual parameters are set correctly and that correct XML is generated using these set parameters. """ uuid = '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000' description = 'This is a dummy secret.' ephemeral = 'yes' private = 'no' secret = config.LibvirtConfigSecret() designer.set_secret_config(secret, uuid, description=description, ephemeral=ephemeral, private=private) expected_xml = """ <secret ephemeral="%s" private="%s"> <description>%s</description> <uuid>%s</uuid> </secret> """ % (ephemeral, private, description, uuid) observed_xml = secret.to_xml() self.assertEqual(ephemeral, secret.ephemeral, 'secret ephemeral flags must match') self.assertEqual(private, secret.private, 'secret private flags must match') self.assertEqual(description, secret.description, 'secret descriptions must match') self.assertEqual(uuid, secret.uuid, 'secret UUIDs must match') self.assertThat(observed_xml, matchers.XMLMatches(expected_xml), message="secret XML segments must match")

commit_message:
Add the OVA container format

An OVA package is a tar archive usually containing an OVF directory
inside it. Nova needs to be able to differentiate OVF and OVA based on
the container format in order to extract the relevant information from
it.
This patch adds the OVA container format to the Glance configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1286375

Change-Id: I5034d2943907823a9296e7a5fb41a28f2d92ec5a

commit_message:
NEC plugin: PFC packet fitler support

It also enhances the following points of packet filter code:
- Allow to clear filter fields to wildcard by specifying None
  in PUT method
- Return None for wildcard fields in an API response
- Determine eth_type based on protocol field on DB layer
- Support OFC driver-specific API validation and update support
- Refactor packet filter code and better validations

Implements blueprint nec-packet-filter-pfc
Change-Id: I2b208c66a9f119ef6d2ef78079d9a7e5965202e7

commit_message:
Add namespaces to xml in Network client

If tag contains ":" it can't be just added to xml. We should set
namespaces to use it correctly.

Change-Id: Ib533a8d876599840c043e4cf6254031da8e7f790

added_lines: NAMESPACES = { 'router': "http://docs.openstack.org/ext/neutron/router/api/v1.0", 'provider': 'http://docs.openstack.org/ext/provider/api/v1.0', } elements = set() if ":" in name: elements.add(name.split(":")[0]) if elements: self._add_namespaces(post_body, elements) def _add_namespaces(self, root, elements): for element in elements: root.add_attr('xmlns:%s' % element, self.NAMESPACES[element])

commit_message:
Store URI must start with the expected  URI scheme

Add a check to make sure the store location URI starts
with the expected scheme.
Also add some more tests for the location.

Change-Id: I4ef360b3444d29de209a6e90a5ff29bd74f21155
Closes-Bug: #1287495
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/70/77770/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: STORE_SCHEME = 'vsphere' self.scheme = self.specs.get('scheme', STORE_SCHEME) if not uri.startswith('%s://' % STORE_SCHEME): reason = _("URI must start with %s://") % STORE_SCHEME LOG.error(reason) raise exception.BadStoreUri(uri, reason) return (STORE_SCHEME,) self.scheme = STORE_SCHEME

commit_message:
fix tgt to use 'service' instead of upstart calls

the comments in here were largely about oneric, which we don't
support any more. service is installed in a precise environment,
and will support debian and the upcoming transition to systemd
better, so use that instead.

Change-Id: If15493549a8c93a7387df9b3bba31443aed46995
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/89/77889/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo service tgt restart
deleted_lines: # tgt in oneiric doesn't restart properly if tgtd isn't running # do it in two steps sudo stop tgt || true sudo start tgt

fix typo in lib/ceilometer

sure why it passes in the gate, but it fails in stackforge jobs.

commit_message:
Split out config option registration

This commit takes the option registration and local attr settings from
the tempest private config object and splits them out as separate
functions. This exposes a way to register the config options without
creating a config object. This enables the config options and defaults
to be more easily used for unit tests and external utilities, such as
the sample generator.

Change-Id: I2ed7e33a14e652f0ec9be2cce069b4925c02b3bd

commit_message:
Prepare for enabling H302 rule(services/compute/json)

Currently H302 rule is ignored by tox. However, this rule should
be enabled. This patch partially fixes this problem to prepare for
H302 rule.

Change-Id: I93204fb215b54b8a304224b249320428870dedde

commit_message:
Move the metrics update to get_metrics

It is not necessary to update the metrics when get every metric in
one compute monitor plugin, just update once when get metrics for
the monitor plugin.

Change-Id: Ib665188964de8318f6d94343891666c674111c8c

commit_message:
Check if snapshot is deleted cleanly.

This patch added a check in delete_snapshot to make sure the
snapshot is deleted cleanly.  Without this check, if someone
tries to delete the source volume immediately after the snapshot
deletion, it will fail with error that the volume still has
snapshot.

Closes-Bug: #1286699

Change-Id: Idf4508025b403fa572584e5204b3891375fed6c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/48/77348/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # It takes a while for the relationship between the snapshot # and the source volume gets cleaned up. Needs to wait until # it is cleaned up. Otherwise, the source volume can't be # deleted immediately after the snapshot deletion because it # still has snapshot. This fix is needed to pass certification test. s_totalloop = self._get_timeout() wait_interval = 10 i_totalloop = int(s_totalloop) / wait_interval loop = 1 while True: try: sync_name, storage_system =\ self._find_storage_sync_sv_sv(snapshot, volume, False) if sync_name is None: LOG.info(_('Snapshot: %(snapshot)s: volume: %(volume)s. ' 'Snapshot is deleted.') % {'snapshot': snapshotname, 'volume': volumename}) break time.sleep(wait_interval) loop = loop + 1 if loop > i_totalloop: LOG.warn(_('Snapshot: %(snapshot)s: volume: %(volume)s. ' 'Snapshot deleted but cleanup timed out.') % {'snapshot': snapshotname, 'volume': volumename}) break except Exception as ex: # 6 means object not found, so snapshot is deleted cleanly if ex.args[0] == 6: LOG.info(_('Snapshot: %(snapshot)s: volume: %(volume)s. ' 'Snapshot is deleted.') % {'snapshot': snapshotname, 'volume': volumename}) else: LOG.warn(_('Snapshot: %(snapshot)s: volume: %(volume)s. ' 'Snapshot deleted but error during cleanup. ' 'Error: %(error)s') % {'snapshot': snapshotname, 'volume': volumename, 'error': str(ex.args)}) break def _get_timeout(self, filename=None): if filename is None: filename = self.configuration.cinder_emc_config_file file = open(filename, 'r') data = file.read() file.close() dom = parseString(data) timeouts = dom.getElementsByTagName('Timeout') if timeouts is not None and len(timeouts) > 0: timeout = timeouts[0].toxml().replace('<Timeout>', '') timeout = timeout.replace('</Timeout>', '') LOG.debug(_("Found Timeout: %s") % (timeout)) return timeout else: LOG.debug(_("Timeout not specified.")) return 10

commit_message:
Handle API limit exception in nova_utils.refresh_server

novaclient raises an OverLimit exception when a 413 response code (API
limit) is returned from the Nova API.  Previously, this would cause the
stack action to fail.  Log a warning instead.

Change-Id: I52c9dc96b34d0645662d98aaeebb7dabe6956e25
Implements: blueprint improve-api-polling

commit_message:
Adds support for Nova RDP console

Hyper-V employs RDP to access virtual machine consoles, unlike most
other hypervisors which support VNC.

In order to support this scenario, the get_rdp_console API has been
added to Nova. This commit adds the corresponding UI feature,
implemented in a way consistent with existing VNC and SPICE console
support.

Change-Id: I9722a1aef5d26184f5a6bc278e306acbdae76b7b
Blueprint: hyper-v-rdp-console

""" _attrs = ['url', 'type'] def server_rdp_console(request, instance_id, console_type='rdp-html5'): return RDPConsole(novaclient(request).servers.get_rdp_console( instance_id, console_type)['console'])

run_tests.sh default doc omits pep8

  Modified run_tests.sh comments to show that
  both pep8 and unit tests are run by default

   Closes-Bug: #1280866

commit_message:
Switch over to oslosphinx

oslosphinx is now available as a replacement for oslo.sphinx that
won't conflict with oslo.config in virtual envs

Change-Id: I7dc3349c8102cc8f358de7e0088128b6705c5f8e
Closes-Bug: #1277168
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/67/73367/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: You'll need to install python *Sphinx* package and *oslosphinx* sudo pip install sphinx oslosphinx
deleted_lines: You'll need to install python *Sphinx* package and *oslo.sphinx* sudo pip install sphinx oslo.sphinx

commit_message:
Update HP 3PAR Driver Documentation to Reflect Change I72e0a76c

This patch updates the HP 3PAR driver documentation to reflect
Change I72e0a76c. System Requirements now state that HP 3PAR
Operating System 3.1.3 or higher is required (changed from
3.1.2 (MU3) )

Documentation now states that

Change-Id: I9aaa3425bacfbf632ec500f6bc11cb3f83db2c76
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/96/75696/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>HP 3PAR Operating System software version 3.1.3 or higher</para>
deleted_lines: <para>HP 3PAR Operating System software version 3.1.2 (MU3) or higher</para>

subject: Add GlanceLogFile and GlanceNotifierStrategy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-26 20:54:45.000000000', 'files': ['notcompute.yaml', 'undercloud-source.yaml', 'overcloud-source.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/49915844e0c709ab05e1c882eb5936d810850a94', 'message': 'Add GlanceLogFile and GlanceNotifierStrategy

Expose 2 new parameters to control glance configuration:
- GlanceLogFile
- GlanceNotifierStrategy

This will allow the glance configuration options log_file and
notifier_strategy to be set in glance-api.conf and glance-registry.conf

Change-Id: I1af1ecfdfe0859f2baba4579aab6e947a2a54308
'}]
commit_message:
Add GlanceLogFile and GlanceNotifierStrategy

Expose 2 new parameters to control glance configuration:
- GlanceLogFile
- GlanceNotifierStrategy

This will allow the glance configuration options log_file and
notifier_strategy to be set in glance-api.conf and glance-registry.conf

Change-Id: I1af1ecfdfe0859f2baba4579aab6e947a2a54308
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/52/76652/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: GlanceNotifierStrategy: Description: Strategy to use for Glance notification queue Type: String Default: noop GlanceLogFile: Description: The filepath of the file to use for logging messages from Glance. Type: String Default: '' notifier-strategy: Ref: GlanceNotifierStrategy log-file: Ref: GlanceLogFile

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-06-18 08:33:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/63496a0be8a11a94c4568481ea9d66ca2b99d86d', 'message': 'PoC

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-06-19 07:06:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6dc1e3b3f72d06f8095d42e8d2b726922f952f73', 'message': 'Adding image multiple location support

Image now support multiple locations within its metadata and it maybe
stored more then one backend storage. Nova should add a layer to
transparent handle image preparing and removing for an instance by the
best approach/location, and it should allow administrator to configure
the image handler pipline with the order who preferred to the layer.

Also, base on this structure we could implement particular sub-class in
relevant hypervisor layer with more advanced functions, such as COW
making, snapshot capturing and etc. in feature.

Implement bp: image-multiple-location
docimpact

Change-Id: Idce8d21ae37bfdbb28a2567120a83d1061061904

transparently handle image preparing and removing for an instance by the
best approach/location, and it should allow administrators to configure
the image handler pipeline with the order who preferred to the layer.

Also, based on this structure we could implement particular sub-class in
relevant hypervisor layer with more advanced functions, such as CoW
making, snapshot capturing and etc. in future.

Implement bp: image-multiple-location
DocImpact

Change-Id: Idce8d21ae37bfdbb28a2567120a83d1061061904

commit_message:
Adding image multiple location support

Images now support multiple locations within its metadata and it may be
stored on more than one backend storage. Nova should add a layer to
transparently handle image preparing and removing for an instance by the
best approach/location, and it should allow administrators to configure
the image handler pipeline with the order who preferred to the layer.

Also, based on this structure we could implement particular sub-class in
relevant hypervisor layer with more advanced functions, such as CoW
making, snapshot capturing and etc. in future.

Implement bp: image-multiple-location
DocImpact

Change-Id: Idce8d21ae37bfdbb28a2567120a83d1061061904
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/33409/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abc import contextlibimport urlparsefrom nova.openstack.common import excutilsfrom nova.openstack.common import importutils cfg.ListOpt('image_handlers', default=[ 'nova.virt.images.DefaultImageHandler' ], help='Which handler class names to use for handling image.' 'Choice class from the list by its order.'), out, _err = utils.execute('env', 'LC_ALL=C', 'LANG=C', with handle_image(context, image_href, _user_id, _project_id, path) as (handler, loc): handler.fetch_image(context, image_href, path, _user_id, _project_id, loc) try: try: with handle_image(context, image_href, user_id, project_id, path_tmp) as (handler, loc): handler.remove_image(path_tmp, context, image_href, user_id, project_id, loc) with handle_image(context, image_href, user_id, project_id, staged) as (handler, loc): handler.move_image(staged, path, context, image_href, user_id, project_id, loc) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): with handle_image(context, image_href, user_id, project_id, staged) as (handler, loc): handler.remove_image(staged, context, image_href, user_id, project_id, loc) fileutils.delete_if_exists(path_tmp) else: with handle_image(context, image_href, user_id, project_id, path_tmp) as (handler, loc): handler.move_image(path_tmp, path, context, image_href, user_id, project_id, loc) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): with handle_image(context, image_href, user_id, project_id, path_tmp) as (handler, loc): handler.remove_image(path_tmp, context, image_href, user_id, project_id, loc) fileutils.delete_if_exists(path_tmp) _image_handlers = [] _image_handlers_asso = {} class ImageHandler(object): """ Image handler base class. """ # TODO(zhiyan): Currently the behavior of this image handler class just # only like a image fetcher. On next step, we could implement # particular sub-class in relevant hypervisor layer with more # advanced functions base on this structure, such as # COW creating and snapshot capturing, etc. def __init__(self, driver): self.driver = driver def get_schemes(self): return () def fetch_image(self, context, image_id, path, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): @utils.synchronized(path) def _fetch(): ret = self._fetch_image(context, image_id, path, user_id, project_id, location) if ret: self._associate(path, location) self._set_handled(ret) _fetch() def remove_image(self, path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): @utils.synchronized(path) def _remove(): ret = self._remove_image(path, context, image_id, user_id, project_id, location) if ret: self._disassociate(path) self._set_handled(ret) _remove() def move_image(self, src_path, dst_path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): @utils.synchronized(src_path + dst_path) def _move(): ret = self._move_image(src_path, dst_path, context, image_id, user_id, project_id, location) if ret: self._disassociate(src_path) self._associate(dst_path, location) self._set_handled(ret) _move() def last_ops_handled(self): res = self._last_ops_handled self._last_ops_handled = False return res def _set_handled(self, handled): self._last_ops_handled = handled @abc.abstractmethod def _fetch_image(self, context, image_id, path, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): pass @abc.abstractmethod def _remove_image(self, path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): pass @abc.abstractmethod def _move_image(self, src_path, dst_path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): pass def _associate(self, path, location): global _image_handlers_asso _image_handlers_asso[path] = (self, location) def _disassociate(self, path): global _image_handlers_asso try: del _image_handlers_asso[path] except KeyError: # Some unit test cases not call fetch_image before reach here pass class DefaultImageHandler(ImageHandler): """ Default image handler class. Using downloading method to fetch image and save to regular file, and use os.unlink to remove image, those like Nova default behavior. """ def __init__(self, driver=None): super(DefaultImageHandler, self).__init__(driver) def _fetch_image(self, context, image_id, path, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): # TODO(vish): Improve context handling and add owner and auth data # when it is added to glance. Right now there is no # auth checking in glance, so we assume that access was # checked before we got here. (image_service, image_id) = glance.get_remote_image_service(context, image_id) with fileutils.remove_path_on_error(path): with open(path, "wb") as image_file: image_service.download(context, image_id, image_file) return os.path.exists(path) def _remove_image(self, path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): fileutils.delete_if_exists(path) return not os.path.exists(path) def _move_image(self, src_path, dst_path, context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, location=None): os.rename(src_path, dst_path) return os.path.exists(dst_path) def load_image_handlers(driver): def _get_class(image_handler_entry): LOG.debug(_("Attempting to import image handler %s") % image_handler_entry) cls = None try: cls = importutils.import_class(image_handler_entry) except ImportError as e: LOG.warn(_("Failed to import image handler " "%(image_handler_entry)s: %(e)s") % locals()) return cls global _image_handlers, _image_handlers_asso if _image_handlers: # Some unit test cases call this more then one time _image_handlers = [] _image_handlers_asso = {} for image_handler_entry in CONF.image_handlers: image_handler_entry = image_handler_entry.strip() if not image_handler_entry: continue image_handler_cls = _get_class(image_handler_entry) if image_handler_cls: image_handler = image_handler_cls(driver) _image_handlers.append(image_handler) @contextlib.contextmanager def handle_image(context=None, image_id=None, user_id=None, project_id=None, target_path=None, default_handler=DefaultImageHandler): def _match_location(locations, schemes): matched = [] for loc in locations: if urlparse.urlparse(loc).scheme in schemes: matched.append(loc) return matched handled = False global _image_handlers, _image_handlers_asso if target_path and _image_handlers_asso: (image_handler, location) = _image_handlers_asso.get(target_path) if image_handler: yield image_handler, location handled = image_handler.last_ops_handled() if not handled and context and image_id and _image_handlers: # TODO(vish): Improve context handling and add owner and auth data # when it is added to glance. Right now there is no # auth checking in glance, so we assume that access was # checked before we got here. (image_service, image_id) = glance.get_remote_image_service(context, image_id) img_locs = image_service.get_locations(context, image_id) if img_locs: for image_handler in _image_handlers: schemes = image_handler.get_schemes() matched_locs = [] if schemes: matched_locs = _match_location(img_locs, schemes) for loc in matched_locs: yield image_handler, loc handled = image_handler.last_ops_handled() if handled: break if not handled: # Use default image handler process this image image_handler = default_handler() yield image_handler, None handled = image_handler.last_ops_handled() if not handled: LOG.error("Cann't handle image: %s" % image_id)

commit_message:
Enable --help for each command

Now heat stack-create --help outputs same with heat --help. It should
output the help message for stack-create instead of the global one.

Change-Id: I1b451ddb4ecba3bb3294ff3219a5ecad394ada9e

commit_message:
NetApp eseries iscsi driver implementation

This change introduces the iscsi
driver for NetApp eseries family of storage
systems. E-series is another  storage
solution offered by NetApp.

Related-Bug: 1278567
Implements: blueprint netapp-eseries--cinder-driver
Certification results: https://launchpadlibrarian.net/166301064/eseries_cinder_certification.log

Change-Id: I8b55d1f1c8de12052281c7cae0c2f89a9d2c3dd1

commit_message:
Add script for purge db (WIP)

This script implements purging DB from soft_deleted rows, with consideration
of tables relationship.

DO NOT MERGE

blueprint db-purge-engine

Change-Id: I7deb8e09ca783b5f030062d03ea5912b443a8b37

added_lines: class DBCleaner(object): def __init__(self, models): """:param models: Module with sqlalchemy models.""" self.models = models self.releationship_tree = dict() self.roots = set() self.tables = dict() def _create_tree_from_module(self): """Just another ugly implementation of db releationship tree.""" for module in dir(self.models): obj = getattr(self.models, module) if '__tablename__' in dir(obj): ref = obj.__tablename__ self.tables[ref] = obj for prop in dir(obj): try: foreign_keys_set = (getattr(obj, prop). property.columns[0].foreign_keys) for i in foreign_keys_set: self._add_to_tree(i, prop, ref) except Exception: pass #select roots self.roots = self.releationship_tree.keys() for node in self.releationship_tree: for fk in self.releationship_tree[node]: for child in self.releationship_tree[node][fk]: if child in self.roots: self.roots.remove(child) def _add_to_tree(self, f_key, prop, ref): key, val = f_key.target_fullname.split('.') if key in self.releationship_tree: if val in self.releationship_tree[key]: if ref not in self.releationship_tree[key][val]: self.releationship_tree[key][val][ref] = prop else: self.releationship_tree[key][val] = {ref: prop} else: self.releationship_tree[key] = {val: {ref: prop}} def _purge_node_with_children(self, node, session): parent_table = self.tables[node] if node in self.releationship_tree: for fk in self.releationship_tree[node]: for child in self.releationship_tree[node][fk]: deleted_rows = (model_query(self.ctxt, parent_table, read_deleted="yes", session=session). filter(parent_table.deleted != 0).all()) child_table = self.tables[child] child_col = getattr(child_table, (self.releationship_tree[node] [fk][child])) for row in deleted_rows: parent_col = getattr(row, fk) (model_query(self.ctxt, child_table, session=session). filter(child_col == parent_col).soft_delete()) self._purge_node_with_children(child, session) m = (model_query(self.ctxt, parent_table, session=session, read_deleted="yes"). filter(parent_table.deleted != 0)) m.delete() def purge_deleted_rows(self, context): @require_admin_context def purge(context): self.ctxt = context self._create_tree_from_module() session = db_session.get_session() with session.begin(): for node in self.roots: self._purge_node_with_children(node, session) purge(context)

subject: Parameterize disk_cachemodes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-04 08:23:56.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/nova_compute_libvirt_spec.rb', 'manifests/compute/libvirt.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/18f55e73e12e40368df2f793d2f99359a0d63cea', 'message': "Parameterize disk_cachemodes

The current manifests don't expose a way for end users to set
the disk_cachemodes directive in nova.conf, which can be useful
for improving disk performance.  This patch adds a parameter
allowing users to specify a list of values to be written in
to the disk_cachemodes setting.  The default value is an empty
list, which will cause the disk_cachemodes setting to be removed
entirely from nova.conf (thus matching the Nova default and
current behavior).

This patch is based on 0a5d6568f070d193b604513f194c966cc224a86b
but is slightly modified to account for a change in how the
nova.conf file is organized between Havana and Icehouse
(some libvirt params were moved from the [DEFAULT] section
to the new [libvirt] section in Icehouse).

Change-Id: I9173ef79e4e573515f290734535907794dda7dbf
(cherry picked from commit 0a5d6568f070d193b604513f194c966cc224a86b)
"}]
commit_message:
Parameterize disk_cachemodes

The current manifests don't expose a way for end users to set
the disk_cachemodes directive in nova.conf, which can be useful
for improving disk performance.  This patch adds a parameter
allowing users to specify a list of values to be written in
to the disk_cachemodes setting.  The default value is an empty
list, which will cause the disk_cachemodes setting to be removed
entirely from nova.conf (thus matching the Nova default and
current behavior).

This patch is based on 0a5d6568f070d193b604513f194c966cc224a86b
but is slightly modified to account for a change in how the
nova.conf file is organized between Havana and Icehouse
(some libvirt params were moved from the [DEFAULT] section
to the new [libvirt] section in Icehouse).

Change-Id: I9173ef79e4e573515f290734535907794dda7dbf
(cherry picked from commit 0a5d6568f070d193b604513f194c966cc224a86b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/19/77819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*libvirt_disk_cachemodes*] # (optional) A list of cachemodes for different disk types, e.g. # ["file=directsync", "block=none"] # If an empty list is specified, the disk_cachemodes directive # will be removed from nova.conf completely. # Defaults to an empty list # $libvirt_type = 'kvm', $vncserver_listen = '127.0.0.1', $migration_support = false, $libvirt_cpu_mode = false, $libvirt_disk_cachemodes = [], if size($libvirt_disk_cachemodes) > 0 { nova_config { 'DEFAULT/disk_cachemodes': value => join($libvirt_disk_cachemodes, ','); } } else { nova_config { 'DEFAULT/disk_cachemodes': ensure => absent; } }

commit_message:
Sanitize file paths

Some absolute paths are computed at runtime and give result that are not
suitable for publishing. This patch sanitize such paths.

Change-Id: I0b4569de50ce6d75f87f2976654d7534bb91df2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/00/77700/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re # Compute the absolute path of the git repository (the relative path is # prepended to sys.path in autohelp.py) target_abspath = os.path.abspath(sys.path[0]) # This regex will be used to sanitize file paths and uris uri_re = re.compile(r'(^[^:]+://)?%s' % target_abspath) if uri_re.search(default): default = default.replace(target_abspath, '/usr/lib/python/site-packages')

commit_message:
autohelp.py: Fix sanitizing of modules paths values

If the git repository path is the name of the module being worked on, some
default values are wrongly modified when the tools tries to generate a saner
value.

commit_message:
Correction in order of parameters of  assertEqual

Here assertEqual(202, resp.status) parameters were used as
(expected, actual).
But actually its order should be (actual, expected).
So this patch changes the assertEqual() with correct parameter
ordering. i.e assertEqual(resp.status, 200)

Change-Id: Ic3c71e888a76441f07a1de028ec4c7e7d58a3159

subject: Make Wait Conditions depend on config creation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-26 22:29:45.000000000', 'files': ['nova-compute-instance.yaml', 'overcloud-source.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/dcfbcb6442cf8bcaf08091a32f6e3d753e4439f9', 'message': "Make Wait Conditions depend on config creation

Currently our wait conditions are racing with Heat resolving
configurations. There should be plenty of time but sometimes Heat may
be dealing with a temporarily problematic Nova API and spinning on that.
While that is happening, the in-instance tools will not have their full
configuration available to them. We don't want the wait condition timeout
to start until the box has had its actual config exposed to it.

Change-Id: I0eab8fe7547d3cbcebb1559fd3d06206b1750e96
"}]
commit_message:
Make Wait Conditions depend on config creation

Currently our wait conditions are racing with Heat resolving
configurations. There should be plenty of time but sometimes Heat may
be dealing with a temporarily problematic Nova API and spinning on that.
While that is happening, the in-instance tools will not have their full
configuration available to them. We don't want the wait condition timeout
to start until the box has had its actual config exposed to it.

Change-Id: I0eab8fe7547d3cbcebb1559fd3d06206b1750e96
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/75/76675/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update README formatting and content

This orders the phase subdirectories by execution order, adds
subheadings, and fixes some markdown formatting issues. This also
replaces all double-spaces after full-stops with single spaces.

Change-Id: I2d5526cbe4a902067fa9cad1456c35d13f81e183
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/80/75480/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ### Phase Subdirectories ### part of the process you need to customise. The subdirectories are executed in the order given here. Scripts within the subdirectories should be named with a two-digit numeric prefix, and are executed in numeric order. * runs: outside chroot* extra-data.d: pull in extra data from the host environment that hooks may need during image creation. This should copy any data (such as SSH keys, http proxy settings and the like) somewhere under $TMP\_HOOKS\_PATH. * runs: outside chroot * inputs: $TMP\_HOOKS\_PATH * outputs: None * pre-install.d: Run code in the chroot before customisation or packages are installed. A good place to add apt repositories. * runs: in chroot * install.d: Runs after pre-install.d in the chroot. This is a good place to install packages, chain into configuration management tools or do other image specific operations. * runs: in chroot * post-install.d: Run code in the chroot. This is a good place to perform tasks you want to handle after the OS/application install but before the first boot of the image. Some examples of use would be: Run chkconfig to disable unneeded services and clean the cache left by the package manager to reduce the size of the image. * runs: in chroot * block-device.d: customise the block device that the image will be made on (e.g. to make partitions). Runs after the target tree has been fully populated but before the cleanup hook runs. * runs: outside chroot * inputs: $IMAGE\_BLOCK\_DEVICE={path} $TARGET\_ROOT={path} * outputs: $IMAGE\_BLOCK\_DEVICE={path} * runs: in chroot are removed here in the dpkg element. * runs: outside chroot### Environment Variables ### To set environment variables for other hooks, add a file to environment.d. This directory contains bash script snippets that are sourced before running scripts in each phase. ### Dependencies ### Each element has a file named element-deps: a plain text, newline separated list of elements which will be added to the list of elements built into the image at image creation time. ### First-boot files ###### Ramdisk Elements ### - An element that installs and configures Nova might be a bit more complex, containing several scripts across several phases: * zero or more driver-elements * one or more service-elements * zero or more config-elementsdiskimage-builder has the ability to retrieve source code for an element and place it into a directory on the target image during the extra-data phase. The default location/branch can then be overridden by the process running diskimage-builder, making it possible to use the same element to track more then one branch of a git repository or to get source for a local cache. See elements/source-repositories/README.md for more information.
deleted_lines: part of the process you need to customise: Runs outside the chroot on the host environment. are removed here in the dpkg element. Runs outside the chroot on the host environment. * block-device.d: customise the block device that the image will be made on (e.g. to make partitions). Runs outside the chroot, after the target tree has been fully populated but before the cleanup hook runs. * outputs: $IMAGE\_BLOCK\_DEVICE={path} * inputs: $IMAGE\_BLOCK\_DEVICE={path} $TARGET\_ROOT={path} * extra-data.d: pull in extra data from the host environment that hooks may need during image creation. This should copy any data (such as SSH keys, http proxy settings and the like) somewhere under $TMP\_HOOKS\_PATH. * outputs: None * inputs: $TMP\_HOOKS\_PATH * pre-install.d: Run code in the chroot before customisation or packages are installed. A good place to add apt repositories. * install.d: Runs after pre-install.d in the chroot. This is a good place to install packages, chain into configuration management tools or do other image specific operations. * post-install.d: Run code in the chroot. This is a good place to perform tasks you want to handle after the OS/application install but before the first boot of the image. Some examples of use would be: Run chkconfig to disable unneeded services and clean the cache left by the package manager to reduce the size of the image. * environment.d: Bash script snippets that are sourced before running scripts in each phase. Use this to set an environment variable for other hooks. * element-deps : A plain text, newline separated list of elements which will be added to the list of elements built into the image at image creation time.- An element that installs and configures Nova might be a bit more complex: zero or more driver-elements one or more service-elements zero or more config-elements- diskimage-builder has the ability to retrieve source code for an element and place it into a directory on the target image during the extra-data phase. The default location/branch can then be overridden by the process running diskimage-builder, making it possible to use the same element to track more then one branch of a git repository or to get source for a local cache. See elements/source-repositories/README.md for more information.

commit_message:
Separation of tests by folders and gate-docs fix

For unittests was created new directory and all such tests were moved
there. Also, .testr.conf was edited, where directory
magnetodb/tests/unittests' was set by default tox executing.

'tests.unittests.api.test_boto' and 'storage.model' were edited to back
compatibility with Python 2.6 and README.rst was updated with actual
values (stackforge) as well.

Also, 'sphinx' support was added.

Change-Id: I5d182644f692f4ca874185139cb72990040215eb
Closes-Bug: #1287144
Closes-Bug: #1287187

commit_message:
Move vbd plug/unplug into session object

To make it easier not to miss the VBD plug/unplug workaround I have
moved this into the xenapi object, overriding the regular method.

Change-Id: Ia0e677824b2bf700c5fb73a75c335f74a6ebb6a2

commit_message:
Minor refactoring for Hyper-V utils and tests

A separate commit in the blueprint addressed by this patch
introduces the "_filter_acls" and "_create_acl" methods
which can be used in "enable_port_metrics_collection"
as well to reduce code duplication.

This commit eliminates also some code duplication
in test_hyperv_utilsv2.py.

Implements: blueprint hyperv-security-groups

Change-Id: I48fb5389b6049641ca2649990e81e94e4c45ef7f

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V Security Groups implementation

Implements the security groups API in the Hyper-V agent.

To enable security groups on the Hyper-V agent, its config file
must contain the following option:

[SECURITYGROUP]
firewall_driver=neutron.plugins.hyperv.agent.security_groups_driver.HyperVSecurityGroupsDriver

Change-Id: I7556001557cd013c10b7f883dbf371afa8d09626
Implements: blueprint hyperv-security-groups
